Posted By: Champion_Kitsune (10/25/2009 9:07:17 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
An odd bit of history from the days before Color Pie was altered to give us [Naturalize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Naturalize). Back in the Weatherlight-era environment, this was one of a tiiiiny handful of green spells that could destroy artifacts directly. The high cost seemed justified back then.  
  
These days this card is pretty bad. [Oxidize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oxidize) blows it out of the water.  
  
Also, it's an absolute shame such an awesome name got wasted on a card like this.
posts.html:
An odd bit of history from the days before Color Pie was altered to give us Naturalize. Back in the Weatherlight-era environment, this was one of a tiiiiny handful of green spells that could destroy artifacts directly. The high cost seemed justified back then.

These days this card is pretty bad. Oxidize blows it out of the water.

Also, it's an absolute shame such an awesome name got wasted on a card like this.

Posted By: DaaNz (3/14/2009 3:05:45 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Too expensive, of course. But definitely nor useless, like [Sorrow's Path](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sorrow's Path) or [Wood Elemental](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wood Elemental). There have been games when I have wished my [Noble Hierarch](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Noble Hierarch), [Eternal Witness](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Eternal Witness), [Harmonize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Harmonize) or something else were this instead. That has never been the case with the truly sucky cards of Magic - this is just outclassed, not bad per se.
